Children and Young People Diabetes Standard Operational Policy/ 14013 / 3.0
Page  of
Purpose
To describe in detail the Children's Diabetes Service provided jointly by MEHT and PROVIDE in Primary and Secondary care.

To outline the key working relationships between the members of the multidisciplinary team (MDT) to ensure that there is a consistent, coordinated approach to the management and treatment of children and young people diagnosed with diabetes in Mid Essex.
The Children and Young People Diabetes Team follow and adhere to the standards set out in the Best Practice Tariff for paediatric diabetes, introduced in April
2012. The “H” numbers that are referred to in the headings of this policy reflect
the Standards set out in the Best Practice Tariff.
CYPD Hospital Measures: Introduction

The Children's Diabetes Multidisciplinary Team is an integrated service (Mid Essex Hospitals NHS Trust and PROVIDE) serving the population of Mid Essex and the surrounding areas. The Children's Diabetes Team in collaboration with the Adult Team delivers inpatient and outpatient diabetes services to 0 -19 year olds within a population base of around 170 000 people across Mid Essex.
This service is delivered as part of the East of England Children and Young People's Diabetes Network.
Inpatient facilities are provided for young people under 16 years of age on the Children's Ward (Phoenix) at Broomfield Hospital. Young people between the
ages of 16 years and 19 years with DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis) are admitted to Phoenix /Medical HDU and are cared for jointly by the adult and children and young people teams.

The service currently holds MDT clinics based in the Children's Outpatients Department and all patients are offered appointments a minimum of 4 times a year. Extra contacts with patients are also offered in the community by the PDSN's and Dietician. The service works closely with the Adult Diabetes service and hold transition clinics jointly in the Children's Outpatients department twice a year.
Aims and Objectives of the CYPD Team

The MDT aims to provide consistent co-ordinated care to children/families and young people with diabetes with the ultimate aim of empowering them to manage their diabetes and to embrace a healthier lifestyle.
The MDT is committed to:

Work with children/families and young people (C&YP) with diabetes to support their diabetes education to gain confidence in self-management and to enable them to achieve all aspects of normal development
Providing comprehensive and updated information to the families as part of their educational programme including interactive group sessions
Involving parents, children and young people in the evaluation and organisation of the service
To submit data annually to the National Paediatric Diabetes Audit
To maintain an up to date database of children under the care of the Multi- Disciplinary Team (MDT)
To hold 3 monthly governance meetings and high HbA1c review sessions

Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service
that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 1)
Scope
The Trust's Children and Young People's Diabetes MDT adhere to the network clinical guidelines which are based on the BSPED* and ISPAD** guidelines.
* British Society for Paediatric Endocrinology and Diabetes ** International Society for Paediatric and Adolescent Diabetes
The service, in partnership with the adult diabetes team provides care to children and young people from birth up to  years with Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes.

A service specification for the delivery of the children and young people's diabetes services at Broomfield Hospital has been agreed between MEHT and the local children's commissioners, following the criteria set out in the Paediatric Diabetes Best Practice Tariff, introduced from 1st April
Trust Wide Management Group (H1)

The Adult and Children's Diabetes Management Group is responsible for the co- ordination of children and young people diagnosed with diabetes under the care of the Trust. This group is chaired by the Clinical Lead for the children's diabetes service and meets three times per year. Minutes are to be taken and documented electronically for governance and assurance purposes. This group is accountable to the Patient Safety Group which feeds into the Trust Board. This group holds the right to table discussion at the Elective Care Group should performance or capacity concerns dictate.

The MDT sits in the Women and Children's Directorate of the Trust. There are 3 children's groups that meet quarterly. Children's Urgent and Emergency Group, Children's Safe Surgery Group and the Safeguarding Children's Group are all groups that feed into the Directorate Governance monthly meetings.
The Children and young people's Diabetes MDT hold regular meetings to review caseload and training needs, the remit of this group includes review of service relating to:
DKA prevention;
Hypo-glycaemia;
HbA1c performance;
Junior doctor/staff nurse training;
MDT members training and personal development.

data.text: Twenty-four Hour Advice Service (H2)

The Best Practice Tariff mandates the existence of a 24 hour advice service, seven days a week. The Out of Hours telephone advisory service rota is shared between 4 Diabetes specialist nurses and 2 Diabetes consultants one week at a time starting
on a Friday at 5pm and ending on a Friday at 9am.
For telephone advice on diabetes management to patients/carers;
For telephone advice to health care professionals on the management of CYPs with diabetes admitted to hospital;
For this local team's escalation policy to tertiary centre at the Children's Acute Transport team to manage severe DKA in HDU/PICU.
In the event of patients or health professionals requiring expert advice on diabetes management, this can be obtained by contacting:

During normal office hours (0900 to 1700) on Monday to Friday patients can seek advice by contacting the Children's Diabetes team on 01245 513461 or PDSN until 1700 hours on 07976246208, 07580913171, 07580912610;
After 1700 hours and at weekends patients should contact the Out of Hours telephone advisory service on 078805008020;
Generic e-mail address for diabetes nurses and dietician:
mie-tr.BroomfieldCDT@nhs.net
Out of hours contact information is provided to the patient/parent on diagnosis through an age-banded ‘New diagnosis pack'.
Device Download Facilities (H3)
Out-patient services are based at A101, Broomfield Hospital.

Patients are encouraged to download at home using the appropriate software for their devices, and the clinic is able to view the information remotely or through email and give advice as required prior to clinic if necessary. At each out-patient visit, shared data is reviewed and management plans discussed. We regularly use Roche Insight, Carelink, Diasend, Libreview and Dexcom Clarity in clinic. Blood sugar meters used are mainly Roche Expert smart meters and these are downloaded during MDT clinic. We also encourage diabetes self- management using Diabetes apps ( MyLife, MySgr) where data is also shared.
Point of Care Testing for HbA1c (H4)
On arrival at clinic patients have their weight, height, and blood pressure measured and the clinic nurse takes a blood sample for point of care testing of IFCC HbA1c measurement.

HbA1c is reported in mmol/mol (IFCC) and %(DCCT) via printout and taped into the clinic notes. This is also entered into the electronic diabetes management system (Diamond) and when the clinic letter to the GP is generated from this, a copy is sent to the family. All results are available for the consultation as the hospital pathology results interfaces with the diabetes database.
The point of care HbA1c DCA2000 machines are tested and calibrated before every diabetes clinic. Currently the UK WEQAS standards are complied with. Print outs can be provided as required.
Paediatric Ward Staff Training (H5)
Training for ward staff is provided on a regular basis with additional sessions when required.
The training programme for health care professionals for all wards where CYP with diabetes may be admitted includes:
The management of children and young people newly diagnosed with diabetes;
The use of all equipment used specifically for children and young people with diabetes including insulin pumps and glucose monitors;
The principles of dietary management including offering Level 3 carbohydrate counting from diagnosis;
The safe use of insulin;
The management of hypoglycaemia;
The management of children and young people in diabetic keto-acidosis (DKA.);
The care of children and young people with diabetes undergoing surgery.
Paediatric medical trainees receive training about Diabetes emergencies At induction, DKA guidelines are signposted and teaching is again included in the departmental teaching programme.
DKA management is also included in the Emergency Department nursing and medical staff teaching programme.
An attendance register is completed and a database of staff's current Diabetes training is kept by the ward manager.
Outpatients' Consultation Time (H6)

At each clinic appointment, the CYP is offered consultation with all members of the multidisciplinary team (MDT), defined as including a doctor, paediatric diabetes specialist nurse and paediatric diabetes specialist dietitian. The psychotherapist is present regularly in a few MDT slots per month. They also take referrals and will see the CYP and their family outside of the Children's OPD. Clinic rooms are available for extra input from MDT members with the CYP if required.

The CYP routinely sees all team members and if any team member is not present, they would have had a separate review over the telephone. However the consultant is present at every MDT clinic appointment.
If mental health issues are identified unrelated to diabetes, self-referral to the EWMHS is encouraged, or support can be accessed through www.kooth.com or www.northessexiapt.nhs.uk

Each appointment is scheduled to last for at least 30 minutes to allow time for reviewing the equipment downloads, the interpretation of results and discussion to gain a clear picture of the current situation. Transition aged patients are offered the opportunity of attending clinic on their own, followed by attendance with their carer.
CYPD MDT Measures
Leadership arrangements and responsibilities (M1)
13.1.1 The appointed Lead Clinician's responsibilities include:
Attend the CYPD network meetings;
Ensure diabetes guidelines are updated;
Coordinate the regular review of the MDT action log and high HbA1c meetings making sure the minutes are recorded and acted upon;
Review audit programme;
Produce annual report and work plan;
Overseeing the professional development of multidisciplinary team members;
Maximise the opportunities for the team with the introduction of Best Practice Tariff and Peer review.
Deputy Lead Clinician
13.2.1 The appointed Deputy Lead Clinician's responsibilities are to provide cover for the Lead clinician at all times:
Responsibility for the overall management of the service;
To chair the Diabetes Management Group meetings and ensure accurate minutes are taken;
Represent the Trust at the network Paediatric Diabetes meetings attending at least two-thirds;
Ensure guidelines are updated;
Review audit programme;
Produce annual report;
Ensure that adequate cover arrangements are in place for MDT members during periods of absence;
Act as an advocate for patients as appropriate;
Ensure that all relevant patients are included for any clinical trials;
Act as or identify a Service Improvement Lead for the MDT.

data.text: Core Nurses
The responsibilities of Core Nurse Members are as follows:
Contribute to multidisciplinary team and patient assessment/care.
Provide specialist educational and training support to patients, parents and schools, promoting holistic care.
Provide link nurse responsibilities to their named patients, contributing towards high HbA1c meeting and informing team of specific problems.
Liaising with key workers including schools on behalf of their patients.
Contribute towards the efficient management of the team, completing templates and utilising new ideas and research as discussed by the team.
Contribute towards audit.
Acting as advice and expert resource for other professionals.
Maintain up to date knowledge base and understanding all aspects of diabetes care and how it relates to dietetics and healthy living.
Core Dietitians
The responsibilities of Core Dietitian members are as follows.
Contribute towards the multidisciplinary discussion and patient assessment/care.
Provide expert dietetic advice and support to other healthcare professionals.
Lead on education of patients, parents, AHPs, kitchen staff and other staff on CHO counting and dietary management.
Advice for schools as necessary particularly in relation to school menus.
Development of written information resources for children and families in relation to dietary management of diabetes, with the EoE network or the hospital trust.

Maintain up to date knowledge base and understanding all aspects of paediatric dietary management and paediatric diabetes care and how it relates to dietetics, complication management and healthy living. Plan and organise group education
workshops as necessary.
Psychologists Core Members
The responsibilities of Psychologists Core member(s) are as follows.
Contribute towards the multidisciplinary discussion and patient assessment/care.
Provide specialist assessment of mental health in CYP and their families and direct psychological interventions in relation to psychosocial aspects of living with diabetes.
Signposting and referral on to local and regional mental health and social care services.
Coordination of annual screening for emotional well-being in CYP and their families.
Provision of consultation and advice to MDT members and other professionals from external agencies in relation to psychosocial adjustment.
Ongoing service development in line with relevant policies/guidance to enhance the overall psychological care provided to families.
Development of information resources available to children and families in relation to emotional well-being.
Participation in service evaluation and audit to further improve psychological care and incorporate patient-rated experience.
Providing support and advice to the Children's Diabetes team during monthly psychology feedback meetings.

The responsibilities of the Administrator is as follows.
Act as consultant/team secretary.
Support the team in organising meetings, liaising with parents etc.
Ensure the diabetes letter templates are updated.
Maintain diary of events, staff holidays etc.

The responsibilities of Data Clerk/Administrator are as follows
Act as data administrator for the team.
Support the team in ensuring accurate data collected and validated by clinicians.

Clinical Guidelines (M3)

The  team  works  within  the  NICE  guidelines  (2015)  and  ISPAD  (2014)/BSPED (2015) in all aspects of diabetes management. As we are part of the East of England  Children's  Diabetes  Network,  we  have  adapted  all  network  guidelines for local use. Guidelines are available in the intranet as well as external hospital website.  Diabetes  guidelines  are  signposted  to  all  new  junior  doctors  at induction.

data.text: TRANSITION CLINIC
Primary Care Communication (M5)
Following receipt of a diabetes diagnosis, the patient's GP is notified by end of the
second working day following discharge. The manner of communication is by
electronic discharge summary as all prescriptions (TTAs) will be stated to facilitate repeat prescriptions.
Patient Choice of Insulin Pump Therapy (M6)

All patients fulfilling the NICE clinical guideline CSII – TA151 are offered the option of insulin pump therapy as an alternative to multiple daily injection (MDI). Patients fulfilling criteria for insulin pump therapy are offered pump assessment clinic appointments. Departmental Insulin pump guideline based on NICE guidance on
insulin pump therapy in young children is followed.
Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) (M7)

All children and young people with type1 diabetes who have frequent severe hypoglycaemia and all other criteria as listed in NICE, are offered flash CGM on prescription if age appropriate. Funding application is then undertaken for on-going real-time continuous glucose monitoring with alarms if hypo-unawareness persists and there is no reduction of hypoglycaemia.
Multidisciplinary Follow-Up Appointments (M8)

Once a new diabetic is discharged from Phoenix ward, they will be followed up in the community by the PDSN and dietician. A multidisciplinary clinic appointment in Children's Outpatients is given within 4-6 weeks of discharge. All children with diabetes have their HbA1C (DCA2000) taken, weight, height, BP and urinalysis prior to being seen. All clinics are supported by a clinic nurse and nursery nurse. MDT appointments are offered 4 times a year as per BPT if Hba1c is less than 8.5%, 2monthly MDT clinic appointments are offered if Hba1C is >8.5%

Each patient is offered at least 4 hospital appointments per year in a multi- disciplinary diabetes clinic, with an annual assessment to decide whether clinical psychologist input is required. In addition to this the MDT makes 8 additional contacts in the form of clinic appointments/visits/texts/phone calls/e-mails, recording contacts electronically (SystmOne).
Patients may also receive separate appointments with the Paediatric Diabetes Dietician.
Patients with HbA1c >8.5% will have an individualised action plan.
HbA1C Measurement (M9)
This is performed by capillary sample via fingerprick using the DCA2000
machines (2 in the treatment room running concurrently when 2 clinics are being
held at the same time). HbA1c printout is attached to clinic note together with height, weight, BP and urinalysis.
Dietetic Assessment (M10)
Paediatric Diabetes dietician is part of the MDT clinic. Extra dietetic input is offered in clinic as well as annual reviews (Paediatric dietician keeps own database to monitor contacts as per BPT).
23.0 Psychological Assessment (M11)

Access to Psychology Therapy services is in place at routine MDT clinic 1.5 hours a month and also as funded therapy  WTE. This is monitored by monthly meetings (Diabetes Psychological Work Discussion Group) with minutes circulated within the MDT after each meeting.
Additional Contacts (M12)

As per Best Practice tariff requirement, the CYP have 12 contacts a year with 4 of those as MDT appointments. The rest of the contacts are done in between those MDT appointments as follow up contacts in the form of school training, home visits, phone consultation, Out of Hours Telephone Service, emails, whatsapp messaging (popular with the teenagers).We have also offered Skype but no intake for this.
There is also an increase on CYP and their families having the facility to download their meters, pumps, FGM and CGM devices that phone and email consultations are becoming more frequent.
Did Not Attend Policy (M13)

The process for managing children who DNA is outlined in the Trust Patient Access Policy, all failure to attend appointments, if the appointment was not cancelled in advance, are contacted by the PDNS and a new appointment is sent. Repeated non-attendance is discussed at Multidisciplinary Team meeting and appropriate action taken. The Children's Diabetes team has drafted ‘DNA letters' taking into account local safeguarding policies.
Support for Children in Education (M14)

26.1.1 Children and Young People attending nursery/primary or secondary schools are offered support in terms of school training to manage their diabetes. Arrangements are made to for the Diabetes Nurse to visit the school or college to discuss the care of each newly diagnosed child including writing an individualised care plan discussed with the Child/ family and the school.
26.1.2Training for schools and colleges includes:
Responsibilities of school and college staff for supervising the delivery of/or administering insulin and the supervising of/or testing of blood glucose levels;
Guidelines on care of children with diabetes while in school or college;
Carbohydrate counting of meals;
Management of physical activity;
Guidelines on management of diabetic emergencies;
Safe storage of medicines whilst in school or college including the safe disposal
of sharps
Assessment of competencies of school and college staff is carried out by the Diabetes nurse this includes school day trips and residential trips.
The Children are offered an annual care plan update, drop in sessions for secondary schools, e-learning diabetes awareness for all school staff and is free to access.
The Paediatric Diabetes team offer support to the school for extra funding application if they need extra staff to supervise the Children and Young People with Type 1 Diabetes.

The Paediatric Diabetes Team offer advice, training or support on residential trips, day trips, after school clubs or transport for Children and Young People with special needs. This is in the form of an arranged meeting to discuss specific needs, additional training or a specific care plan needed.
Screening of Children and Young People with Diabetes (M15)
Children and young people with diabetes must be screened according to current NICE guidance. Screening details are included in the DKA and non-DKA guidelines.
In Type 1 disease for:
Coeliac disease at diagnosis;
Thyroid disease at diagnosis and annually thereafter until transfer to adult services;
Retinopathy screening annually from the age of 12 years (GP referral to retinopathy services)
Moderately increased albuminuria (albumin: creatinine ratio [ACR] 3-30 mg/mmol; 'microalbuminuria') from diagnosis
Standard anthropometric data
Blood pressure annually from the age of 12 years
Foot assessment/examination
In Type 2 disease, for:
Hypertension annually starting at diagnosis
Dyslipidaemia annually starting at diagnosis
Retinopathy screening annually from age 12 years
Moderately increased albuminuria (albumin: creatinine ratio [ACR] 3-30 mg/mmol; 'microalbuminuria') from diagnosis
The MDT offers a screening policy in line with the NICE guideline NG18, this
includes:
Transition and Transfer Policy (M16)
The young person and their family are involved at an early stage regarding
transition arrangements and will have met the Adult Diabetes nurse in clinic prior to
the Transition clinic held jointly by the Adult Diabetes physician and Paediatrician in
the Children's Diabetes clinic. These clinics are held twice a year, and co-ordinated

by the Lead Consultant and PDSN. Dates for Transition clinics and future meetings are agreed during the Adult Children's Trust Wide Management group meetings held three times a year. All matters relating to Transition care are discussed in these meetings with a standard agenda and minutes circulated after the meetings.
This policy is in accordance with year of care principles and specifies:
Involvement of the young person and their family in the decision about transfer to adult care;
Involvement of the young person's general practitioner in planning the transfer;
A joint planning meeting between paediatric and adult services;
Allocation of a named coordinator for the transfer of care;
Responsibilities for giving information about transfer to adult care;
A preparation period prior to transfer;
Arrangements for monitoring during the time immediately after transfer.
Key Worker (M18)
The caseload is shared and there is no single named key worker for any particular
patient. We do however have a key worker policy for Insulin Pump patients,
Diabetic inpatients, and also for Transition Adolescents. The single named key
worker will provide care co-ordination, information and communication with the
patient and be an integral member of the patient's multi-disciplinary team. The aim should be to provide continuity of care throughout the patient pathway, with cross
cover between diabetes nurses for the whole caseload.
Responsibilities of the Key Worker for Insulin Pump, diabetic inpatients and Transition care patients.

29.2.1 Continuity of care: to achieve continuity of care, so that the patient knows who to contact for information or support. To introduce themselves proactively to the patient and provide contact details.

29.2.2 Management: to be present when the patient is initiated in their insulin pump therapy or where possible to be present when the adolescent starting the transition process is introduced to the adult diabetes nurse.
29.2.3 Initial assessment: to ensure that a holistic assessment is carried out of the patient's needs.
29.2.4 On-going assessment: to ensure that assessment is repeated at regular intervals to maintain an up-to-date picture of the patient's needs.

29.2.5 Care planning: to ensure that a care plan is drawn up, in conjunction with the parent/guardian and based on information obtained from the initial assessment. Ensure that the care plan is updated at regular intervals as part of the on-going assessment with the patient.
29.2.6 Liaise with primary care: to establish and maintain contact with the patient's GP so that they are kept informed of key developments in treatment and prognosis.
29.2.7 Provide information: to provide timely information to meet needs expressed by the patient, family members and carers.

29.2.8 Notify a change of key worker: whenever a change of key worker is proposed, the original key worker should seek agreement from the patient and the new key worker. Once agreed, the original key worker should notify all professionals involved in the patient's care.

29.2.9 Respond to patient choice: to make the patient aware that they can request a change of key worker if they feel the existing arrangement is not working successfully, and to act upon any such request.
The Key worker for inpatients will be responsible for co-ordinating the training needs of the nursing staff on the wards.
The required competencies for the key worker role are:
Ability to co-ordinate the input of MDT members (liaising with MDT co-ordinator if hospital based);
Basic listening skills;
Ability to treat patients, family members and carers with kindness, dignity and respect;
Ability to offer general support and to communicate honestly and compassionately;
Ability to inform patients, carers and family members about the range of support services available to them
Ability to recognise psychological needs;
Specialist knowledge of paediatric diabetes;
Ability to elicit worries and other feelings by establishing trust and listening in permissive and non-judgemental manner.
Patient Information and Support (M19)

Children and Young People with Diabetes can access a lot of information. This can be done through the Diabetes Team, Diabetes Nurses, Diabetes Consultant. They are given an information pack when they are diagnosed which contains information from both the local Paediatric Diabetes Team (Provide) but also nationally produced by JDRF.

There are various websites available such as Diabetes UK, DigiBete, JDRF(Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation) Children and Young People can access them and find information support and resources. There are also Apps, Twitter, Facebook groups that could offer support.

data.text: Individualised Objectives (M20)
Each  child  and  young  person  has  agreed  individualised  objectives,  which  are reviewed and updated regularly. These must cover:
Life-style goals;
Target blood glucose levels and how to achieve this through insulin adjustment;
Therapeutic interventions (pharmacological and non-pharmacological);
Self-care;
Individualised healthy meal planning for the child/young person and their family including carbohydrate counting and co-morbidities that effect dietary management;

Education and education plan covering, as a minimum, school attended, medication details, what to do in an emergency whilst in school, giving / supervision of injections by school staff and arrangements for liaison with the school;
Early warning signs of problems, especially high and low blood glucose levels, and what to do if these occur;
Who to contact for advice and their contact details;
Planned review date and how to access a review more quickly, if necessary.
Diabetes Self-Management Education (M21)

The aim of the Children's Diabetes team is to provide consistent high quality, age and maturity appropriate education from the time of diagnosis and throughout the diabetes  journey  of  the  child  and  family  so  that  the  individual  can  eventually manage their diabetes with confidence and fit it into their individual lives.

At the time of initial diagnosis each patient is offered a diabetes self-management education programme. Content is varied according to age and this is continued in the form of updates throughout the child or young person's attendance at the Paediatric Diabetes Clinic. The children and young people have their knowledge and competence assessed using an assessment proforma.

Is there a structured, written curriculum?
Yes. At diagnosis, the ACDC checklist is used to commence structured education. Education is then tailored to the family's needs.
Is the programme adjusted to the age and development stage of the child/young person?

Yes- Under 5's, 6-10 primary school, also takes into account the stage of their diabetes knowledge. Workshops: Age 11-15 secondary school Age 15-16 prepare for transition Age 17-18 Transition workshops
Is the programme quality assured against the programme agreed across the Network?

Does the programme fulfil the requirements of NICE NG18 2015 and NICE QS125 2016?
Yes- by the EoE Network as part of their guideline production processes

Yes – it is discussed also within the team meetings.

data.text: Record of Care (M22)
The records of care for Children and Young People with diabetes and their families are held electronically via Diamond for MEHT and Systmone for Provide;

Newly diagnosed patients will have a Family Information leaflet given to them which has the ACDC checklist for structured education. Before discharge a record of their current management is also written for the Child and Young Person and their parents to follow when they get home.

All Children and Young People and their families seen in the MDT clinic are sent a copy of the clinic letter which is generated from the electronic diabetes database DIAMOND, included in the letter are the details of the next clinic appointment.
